TITLESTMT.TITLE: Octovian (Lincoln, Dean, and Chapter Library, MS 91)

PUBLICATIONSTMT.DISTRIBUTOR: University of Michigan, Humanities Text Initiative

AVAILABILITY.P: This text has been made available through the Oxford Text Archive for personal scholarly use only. OTA number: U-1683-A

SOURCEDESC.P: The electronic text was created from a transcription of Lincoln, Dean, and Chapter Library, MS 91 by Frances McSparran. Abbreviations have been expanded without notice, but otherwise the text, spelling, capitalization and punctuation are those of the manuscript. It is therefore a transcription and not an edition, and differs in many respects from the edition published for the Early English Text Society by the Oxford University Press, London and New York, 1986. Pagination conforming to that of the EETS edition has been supplied to facilitate comparison with the final edited version of the text.

EDITORIALDECL.P: Front and back matter from printed edition not included.
Editorial notes from printed edition not included in electronic edition.

BODY.HEAD: Octovian (Lincoln, Dean, and Chapter Library, MS 91)

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1 through 100
DIV1.L: mekyll and littill olde & ȝynge
herkyns all to my talkynge
of whaym j will ȝow kythe
Jhesu fadir, of heuen kynge,
gyff vs all thy dere blyssynge
and make vs glade & blythe
for full sothe sawis j will ȝow synge
off whaym þe worde full wyde gan sprynge
and ȝe will a stownde me lythe
in þe bukes of rome als it es tolde
how byfelle amange oure eldyrs olde
full ofte & fele sythe
somtym byfell ane auenture
in rome þer was ane emperoure
als men in romance rede
he was a man of grete fauoure
and leuede in joye & grete honoure
and doghety was of dede
in tornament nor in no fyghte
in þe werlde þer ne was a bettir knyghte
no worthier vndir wede
octouyane was his name thrughowte
Euirylke man hade of hym dowte
when he was armede one stede
ane emprice he hade to wyffe
one of fayreste þat was onelyffe
thus thies clerkes sayne vs so
seuen ȝeres had þay samen bene
with joy & gamen þam bytwene
and oþir myrthis moo
the seuen ȝere were comen & gone
bot child togedir had þay none
getyn bytwene þam two
þat aftir þam þair land moghte welde
when þat þay drewe till elde
and forthi in hert þam was full woo
and als þe emperoure satt appon a daye
in his chambir hym to playe
with his lady bryghte
he byhelde hir faire lyre
was whyte so blossome on þe brere
that semly was of syghte
a sorow þan to his herte þer rane
forthi þat þay childir hade nane
thaire landis to rewle one ryghte
and by his lady so als he satte
for sorowe his chekes wexe all wate
that was so hende a knyghte
bot when þe lady þat gan aspye
all chaunged þan hir bryghte blyee
and scho syghede full sore
scho felle hir lorde one knees agayne
and of his sorow scho gan hym frayne
and of his mekyll care
sir scho sais if it were ȝour will
ȝoure concelle for to schewe me till
and of ȝour lyffes fare
ȝe wote j ame ȝoure werldes fere
opyn ȝour herte vnto me here
ȝoure comforthe may be þe mare
þan in his armes he gan hir folde
and all his sorow he to hir tolde
and all his hertis wonde
now hafe we seuen ȝere samen bene
and hase no chylde vs bytwene
for fay we sall hythen fownde
and j ne wote how þis land sall fare
bot lyfe in werre and in kare
when we are broghte to grownde
therefore j hafe so mekyll thoghte
þat when j am to bedde broghte
i slepe bot littill stownde
and þan answerde þat lady bryghte
sir j kan rede ȝow full ryghte
gyffe ȝow nothynge ill
a ryche abbaye schall ȝe do make
for oure swete lady sake
and landis gyffe þeretill
and scho will pray hir son so fayre
that we may samen gete an ayere
this land to welde with skyll
an abbaye þan he gerte wyrke soo
and sone he gatt knauechildire two
als it was goddis wyll
with childe þan ȝode þat lady þore
full grete scho wexe with paynnes sore
that was so faire & free
till þe tym felle þat it was soo
the lady hade knauechildir two
that semly weren to see
tythande come to þe emperoure
þere he laye in his ryche towre
a full glade man was hee
two maydynes hym þe bodworde broghte
withowttyn gyftes ȝede þay noghte
aythire hadde townnes three
the emperoure rosse with mylde mode
and till his chambir he hym ȝode
and thankes god his sande
erly are þe daye gan sprynge

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 101 through 200
DIV1.L: he did a pryste his messe to synge
his modir þore he fande
sone scho said j am full blythe
that þe empryse sall haf hyre lyfe
and lyffe with vs in lande
bot mekyll sorowe dose it me
that rome sall wrange ayerde bee
and jn vncouthe hande
modir he sayse why saye ȝe soo
haffe j noghte knauechildir two
i thanke it goddes will
nay certis scho said sone myn
wete þou wele þay are noghte thyn
and þat lykes me full ill
for þou myghte no childir haue
scho hase takyn thy kokes knaue
i will it proue thurgh skyll
a sorowe þere to his herte gan goo
þat wordis moghte he speke no moo
bot ȝod awaye full still
till his chapelle forthe he ȝode
full sory at his messe he stode
als man þat was in kare
his modir jwhils garte calle a knaue
and highte hym grete gyftis to hafe
a thowsande pownde or mare
to the chambir bothe þay tuk þe waye
there þe empryce in childbed laye
all slepede þat were there
for scho had wakyd ryghte longe
in paynes & in thoghte full stronge
or scho delyuered ware
than said þat lady to þat knaue
hye þe faste þi golde to hafe
þou schall be rewarde þis nyghte
haste þe tyte with all thi myghte
preuely þat þou were dyghte
and þat þou were vnclede
softely by hir þou jn crepe
þat scho ne wakyn of hir slepe
for full seke es scho bystadde
whatte for lufe & whatt for drede
into þe ladyes beedd he ȝede
he dyd als scho hym badd
bot euir he droghe hym ferre awaye
for þe rechese þat scho jn laye
full sore þan was he drade
the emperours modir away ȝode þan
and till hir son full tite scho wan
there he att his messe stode
son scho saide þou trowed noghte me
come forthe þou sall þe sothe now see
with hir to chambir he ȝode
bot when þe emperoure sawe þat syghte
for sorowe no worde speke he ne myghte
for he wexe nerhande wode
a scharpe baselarde owte he droghe
þat giltes knaue þere he sloghe
alle was byblede with blode
ay lay þat lady faste and slepee
a dolefull sweuenynge gan scho mete
scho was a wofull wyghte
hir thoghte scho was in wyldyrnes
in thornes & in thyknes
þat scho myghte hafe no syghte
and þer come flyande ouir þe strande
a dragon all full bryghte birnande
þat all schone of þat lyghte
in his palmes alle byrnand so
vp he tuke hir childir two
& away he tuke his flyghte
therewith þe lady bygan to wake
a dolefull gronyng gan scho make
and scho syghede full sare
the emperoure to þe knaue wente
þe hede vp by þe hare he hente
and caste it till hir thare
the lady blyschede vp in þe bedde
scho saw þe clothes all byblede
full mekyll was hir care
scho bygan to skryke & crye
and sythen in swonynge for to ly
hir selfe scho wolde forfare
wordis of this were spoken no mo
to þat lady to þe kirke solde go
als þe lawe was in þat lede
the emperoure made a full riche feste
of kynges & dukes þat were honeste
of many & dyuirse stede
the kynge of calabre allas
that the lady fadir was
thedir þan gan he bede
alle were þay sampnede appon a daye
with grete solace & mekill playe
to þe kyrke that lady ȝede
and þere duellyn þe kynges samen
with joy & myrthe & mekill gamen
at þat mawngery
with gud myrthis þam emange
harpes fethils & full faire songe

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 201 through 300
DIV1.L: cyteles and sawtrye
till þe seuenyghte was gone
with alkyn welthis in þat wone
of myrthis and mynstralsye
was neuir so riche a gedirynge
that hadd so sary a partynge
i sall ȝow tell for why
grete dole for sothe it es to telle
oppon þe haghten daye byfell
herkyns & ȝe may here
the emperoure to þe chambir ȝode
all þe lordes abowte hym stode
with full mery chere
the emperoure said j vndirstande
swylke a nawntir fell in þis lande
by a lady to ȝere
that was ouir taken with swylk a treson
i aske juggement of þis with reson
of hir whate worthy were
when þe emperoure his tale hade tolde
the kyng of calabire answere wolde
he ne wyste whate it bement
he said it es worthi for hir sake
withowtten þe cete a fyre to make
with rightwyse juggement
& when þe fyre es byrnand faste
hir & hir childir in it to caste
till þay to þe dede be bryntte
the emperoure answeres to hym sone
thyn awen doghetir hase it done
i holde to thyn assent
there was dole & grete pete
a fyre þay made withowtten þe cete
with brondes byrnande bryghte
to þe fyre þay ledde þat lady thare
two sqwyers hir childir bare
þat semly weren of syghte
in a kirtyll of sckarlett rede
into þe fyre to take hir dede
all redy was scho dyghte
the kynge of calabire made euyll chere
he ne myghte for sorowe stande hir nere
bothe wepede kynge and knyghte
the lady þan þe sothe to telle
byfore hir lorde one knees scho felle
and bothe hir handis vp helde
scho sayde my lorde for Jhesu sake
graunt me ane orysoune to make
till hym þat alle sall wellde
and þen of me ȝe do ȝoure wyll
the dede þat j am ordeynede till
therto j will me ȝelde
the emperoure graunted hir righte so
ilke a man þan was full woo
that were þat day in þe felde
than þe lady hir one knes þer sette
till Jhesu cryste full sore scho grette
no wondir þoghe hir ware wo
now lorde scho sayd of heuens blysse
this day þou me rede and wysse
and heuen qwene also
mary mayden and modir free
my prayere make j to the
for my childir two
als þou lete þam be borne of me
helpe þat þay crystened may be
or þat þay to þe dede goo
than lordis þat abowte hyr ware
and ladyes felle in swonyng thore
and knyghttes stode wepande
the emperoure stode by hyr full nere
the teris trykylde one his lyre
that wele nere myghte he stande
than spake he wordis of gret pete
and sayde thi dede will j noghte see
with herte nor ȝitt with hande
the emperoure gafe hire leue to goo
and take with hir hir childir two
and flemed hir of his lande
the emperoure gafe hir fowrty pownde
of florence þat were riche & rownde
in romance als we rede
and he bytaghte hir knyghtes two
and bad þat þay solde with hir goo
owt of his lande to lede
two sqwyers hir childyr bare
in stede þer þay were neuir are
and intill vncouthe thede
when scho was flemyd þat was so gent
ilke a lorde to hys lande es went
for sorow þaire hertes gan blede
when þis lady was in a wyldirnes
that full thyke of wylde bestes bysett was
and all wylsom it semed to syghte
thay hir bytaghte hir childir two
gafe hir hir golde & bad hir go
a stye þer laye full ryghte
they bade hir holde þe hye strete
for drede with whilde bestes to mete
that mekill weren of myghte

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 301 through 400
DIV1.L: and agayne þay went with sory mode
& allone þat lady forthe scho ȝode
als a full wafull wyghte
scho hade so wepede þer byforne
that scho þe ryghte way hase sone forlorne
so mekill was hir thoghte
and jnto a wode was ferly thykke
there dales weren depe & cleues wykke
þe ryghte waye fonde scho noghte
in a greue vndir ane hill
scho found a welle full faire & schille
and ane herbere þerby was wroghte
with faire trees it was bysette
the lady sett hir down & grette
for ferrere scho ne moghte
bot by þe welle scho sett hir down
scho gret & cryede with sory sown
for scho was lefte allone
now lorde scho said if it be þi will
in þis wode late me nott spylle
for full will j am of wone
mary mayden qwene of heuen
i pray þe herkyn to my steuen
and mend my carefull mone
so full j am of pyn & wo
that thre dayes es gon & mo
þat mete ne ete j none
and by þat scho had hir childir dyghte
by þat þan wexe it euen myrk nyghte
als scho satt by þe welle
so jn þat herbere down scho laye
till it was lyghte on þe toþir day
that fowlles herde scho þan synge & ȝelle
thare come an ape to seke hir pray
hir one childe scho bare awaye
vp heghe appon ane hyll
what wondir was ȝif hir were wo
when hir child was fro hir so
in swonynge doun scho felle
and in all þe sorow þat scho in was
ryghte so com rynnande a lyones
of wode als scho wolde wede
in swonynge als þe lady laye
hyr oþir childe scho bare awaye
hir whelpes with to feede
whate wonndir was þofe hyr were wo
awaye were borne hir childir two
in swoghe scho lay for drede
bot for it was a kynge sone jwysse
the lyones moghte do it no mys
bot forthe þerwith scho ȝede
there come a fewle full faire of flyghte
a gryffone sayse þe buke he hyghte
ouir þose holtes so hare
the fewle þan was so mekill of myghte
that esyly myghte he bere a knyghte
alle armed þofe he ware
the lyones with þe childe tuke he
and intill ane jle of the see
the gryffone bothe þam bare
the child slepid in þe lyones mouthe
of wele ne wo it ne kouthe
bot god kepid it fro kare
and whane þe lyones gatt fote on lande
full styfly þan gan scho vp stande
als beste bothe stronge & whilde
the gryffone thurgh goddis grace scho sloghe
and of þat fewle scho ete ynoghe
and layde hir by þat childe
the childe sowkyde þe lyones
als it goddis will was
when it þe pappes felide
the lyones gan it wake
and lufe it for hir whelpes sake
and was þerwith full mylde
with hir feete scho made a dene
that lyttill childe jn broghte scho þen
and kepede hym day & nyghte
and ay when hir hungirde sore
scho ȝode & ete of þe gryffone more
þat are was mekill of myghte
and thus als it was goddis will
the lyones byleues þore styll
with þat barne so bryghte
the lady þat was leued allone
to jhesu criste scho made hir mone
als a full wofull wyghte
scho sais jhesu kyng of alle
with carefulle herte to þe j calle
that þou be my socoure
als j was kyngis doghetir & qwene
and emprice of rome hase bene
and many a riche towre
and thorowe þe lessynges es one me wroghte
till mekill sorow þus am j broghte
and owte of myn honoure
this werldes blysse hafe j forlorne
and my two childir er fro me borne
this lyfe may j noghte dowre
this sorowe lorde þat j am jn

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 401 through 500
DIV1.L: full wele j wote es for my syn
welcome be alle thi sande
to þe werlde will j me neuir gyffe
bot serue the lorde whills j may lyfe
into þe holy londe
and ouir an hill þe waye scho name
and to þe grekkes se scho came
and welke appon þe strande
and byfore hir an hauen scho seghe
and a cete with towris full heghe
a redy waye þere scho fand
whan þe lady com þan to þat town
a schipe scho fond all redy bowne
with pylgremes for to fare
scho badd þe schipmen golde & fee
in þat schipp þat scho moghte be
if þat þaire willes it were
a bote þay sente appone þe flode
to þe lady right þer scho stode
a wyghte man jn hir bare
and by þe maste þay badde hir sytt
there myghte no man hir sorowe wete
and ay scho wepede sare
the schippe come sayland by an jle syde
the maystir badd þat þay sold byde
for fresche watir hafe we nane
bysyde þam was a roche on hye
a welle streme þare þay see
come rynnande ouir a stone
two men to þe lande þay sent
heghe vpe ouir þat roche thay went
the welle þay found anone
the lyones laye in hir dene
and was full blythe of þe two men
and full sone scho hade þam slayne
so lange one ankir gan þay ryde
thies two men for to habyde
till none was of the daye
than gan twelue men þam dyghte
with helme & with hawberke bryghte
and till þe lande wente þay
the lyones fonde þay in hir dene
a knauechilde laye sowkand hir þen
and gan with þe lyones to playe
vmwhile þe childe sowkede hir pappe
vmwhile gan þay kysse & clappe
for drede þay fledde awaye
thay tolde þe wondir þat þay seghe
& þat þay fonde on þe roche on heghe
a lyones in hir den
a knauechilde þerin laye
therewith þe lyones gan hir playe
and dede were bothe þaire men
than spake þat lady so mylde
mercy syrris þat es my childe
one land ȝe late me rynn
a bote þay sett appon þe flode
the lady vnto þe lande þer ȝode
full sore wepide þay þen
when scho com on þat roche on heghe
scho ran ywhils þat scho myght dreghe
with full sory mode
the lyones thurgh goddis grace
when scho sawe þe lady face
full debonorly vp scho stode
thurgh þe myghte of mary mylde
scho sufferd þat lady to tak hir childe
and scho forthe with hir ȝode
but when þe schippmen þe lyones seghe
the land durste þay noghte com neghe
for drede þay were nere wode
sum hent an ore & som a sprete
the wylde lyones for to mete
and þaire chippe for to werre
the lady intill þair chippe þay hente
thritty fote aftir þe lyones sprente
durste no man jn hir bere
there was þan bot lyttill glee
for many lepped into þe see
so ferde of hir þay were
bot by þe lady downe scho laye
and with þe childe bygan to playe
and to no man wolde scho dere
they droghe vp saile of riche hewe
the wynd þam owte of hauen blewe
ouir þat wan streme
the fyrste lande þan þat þay seghe
was a cete with towres full heghe
that hyghte jerusalem
als blythe were þay þan of þat syghte
als es þe fowlles when it es lighte
of þe dayes gleme
when it was ebbe & no flode
the lady to þe lande þan ȝode
into þat riche rewme
ouir alle þe cete wyde & longe
of þat lady the worde þan spronge
þat þore one lande was lente
and how scho hade a lyones
broghte owte of wyldirnes

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 501 through 600
DIV1.L: the kyng aftir hir sente
he bad scho solde lett for no thynge
and þe lyones with hir brynge
to þe castelle es scho went
when scho byfore þe kynge þer come
he kende hir for þe emprice of rome
and by þe hande he hir hente
the kyng þan frayned of hir fare
scho tolde hym of hir mekill care
and of hir grete vnryghte
he garte hir duelle with þe qwene stille
scho hadd maydyns redy to will
to serue hir bothe daye & nyghte
the childe þat was so faire & fre
the kyng did it crystened for to be
octouyane it highte
when þe childe was of elde
that he couthe ryde & armes welde
the kyng dubbede hym to knyghte
the lyones þat was so wilde
belefte with þe lady & þe childe
hir comforthe was the more
the lady byleued with þe qwne
with joye & blysse þam bytwene
to couyre hir of hir care
ilke man hir plesyde day & nyghte
to make hir glade with all þair myghte
vnto hir bettur were
in jerusalem thus gan scho duelle
of hir oþir childe now will j telle
that þe ape awaye bare
now comes þe ape þat was wilde
thurgh þe forest with þe childe
ouir þe holttis so hare
als þe ape come ouir a strete
with a knyghte so gan scho mete
als scho þe childe bare
thore faghte þe knyght wondirly longe
agayne þe ape styffe & stronge
his swerde so brake he there
the ape leued þe childe & away ran
the knyght þe child son vp wan
and with it forthe gan fare
forthe with þe child þe knyght went þan
in þe wode mett he owtlawes tene
that mekill weryn of myghte
ȝitt was neuir þe knyghte so wo
for his swerde was brokyn in two
that he myghte nothyng fyghte
if all þe knyghte were kene & thro
those owtlawes wan þe child hym fro
þat was so swete a wyghte
þe knyghte was wondid forsothe to saye
vnnethes his horse bare hym awaye
so dulefully was he dyghte
those owtlawes sett þam on a grene
þe child þay laide þam bytwene
and it faste on þam loghe
þe maystir owtlawe spake þen
grete schame it were for hardy men
if þay a childe sloghe
i rede we bere it here besyde
to þe se with mekill pride
and do we it no woghe
it es comyn of gentill blode
we sall hym selle for mekill gude
for golde & syluir enoghe
two owtlawes þan made þam ȝare
to þe grekkes se þay it bare
þay couthe þe way full ryghte
it was no man þat it seghe
þat þay ne wepid with þaire eghe
so faire it was of syghte
a burgesse of pareche com þan nere
had bene a palmere seuen ȝere
clement þe velayne he hyghte
sirris he said will ȝe þis child selle
the golde will j for hym telle
florence bothe brode & bryghte
for fourty pound hym selle þay wolde
he said full lange may ȝe hym halde
are ȝe hym so selle may
gode men he said be my hode
i trowe ȝe kan ful littill gude
swilke wordis for to saye
golde & siluir es me bot nede
bot twentty pownd j will ȝow bede
and mak ȝow redy paye
the childe þay vnto clement ȝolde
and twentty pownde he þam tolde
and went forthe one his waye
clement hase þe childe boghte
a payneȝere did he to be wroghte
the childe jn forthe to lede
a noresche gatt he hym also
into fraunce with hym to go
that ȝong childe for to fede
home he tuke þe way ful ryghte
and hastede hym with all his myghte
and vnto paresche he ȝede

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 601 through 700
DIV1.L: the burgesche of paresche wer ful fayne
full many went clement agayne
a slavyne was his wede
thay haylsest clement & kyssed hym alle
and broghte hym till his awen haulle
his wyfe was glade & blythe
scho hym fraynede þe ryght dome
how he to þe childe come
he tolde hir also swythe
in þe holy lond j hym gatt
and þore j wold hym noghte lett
þe sothe j will the kythe
his wyfe ansuerde with herte mylde
he sall be myn awen childe
scho kyste hym ful ofte sythe
clement saide to his wyfe tho
sen þe childe es getyn so
in þe hethen thede
and now es it to þis land broghte
i pray the dame þat þou greue þe noghte
and riche sall be thi mede
sir scho said with wordis free
full welecom es it vnto me
full faire sall j hym fede
and ȝeme hym with oure awen child
to þat he come of helde
and clothe þam in one wede
clement was þerof full blythe
he garte crysten þe child ful swythe
it was not duellid þat nyghte
and als it es in romance tolde
the right name þat þay it callde
florent þe child hyghte
and when þe child was seuen ȝere olde
he was bothe wysse faire & bolde
the man þat redis righte
alle þe rewme wyde & longe
worde of þe childe spronge
so was he faire to syghte
euir þe burgesse & his wyfe
loffed þe childe als þaire lyfe
with þam he was full dere
when he was tuelue ȝere olde & more
he sett his owun son to þe lore
to be a chawndelere
and florent bytaughte he oxen two
and bad hym ouir þe bryge go
vnto a bouchere
to lere his crafte for to do
als hym was neuir of kynd þerto
to vse swylke mystere
als florent ouir þe brygge gan go
dryvand on his oxen two
a semely syghte sawe he
a sqwyere bare als j ȝow telle
a gentill fawcon for to selle
that semly was to see
florent to þe sqwyere ȝede
and bothe his oxen he gan hym bede
for þat fowle so fre
þe sqwyere þerof was full glade
he tuke þe oxen als he hym bade
florent was blythe in ble
the sqwyere hasted hym to go
merueylle þerof thynkes mee
if þou and alle thi men will blyn
i will vndirtake to wynn
paresche þat stronge cete
bot mersabele þan weedde j will
sayd þe sowdane j halde þertill
with thi þat it so bee
arageous appon þat same daye
to þe mount martyn þer þe lady laye
the waye he tuke full ryghte
and hir hade leuir dede to hafe bene
than hym in hir chambir to hafe sene
so fulle he was of syghte
he sayse leman kysse me belyue
thy lorde me hase þe graunte to wyefe
and paresche j hafe hym hyghte
and j hete the wittirly
the kynges heuede of fraunce certanely
tomorowe or it be nyghte
the mayden sayse with mylde mode
to þe geaunte þer he stode
and gaffe hym this answere
the kynges heuede if þou me brynge
than sall þou hafe thyne askynge
for full lefe to me it were
thane armede þe geaunt hym ful wele
bothe in jryn and in stele
with helme and schelde and spere
it was twenty fote and twoo
bytwyxe his crown & his too
there myghte none horse hym bere
the geaunte tuke þe ryghte waye
vnto paresche þat ilke daye
with hym wente no moo
he lenede hym ouir þe towne walle
and thus he spake þe folke with alle

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 701 through 800
DIV1.L: wordis kene and throo
he badde þay solde send owte a knyghte
þat myghte hym fynde his fill of fyghte
ore he þat londe wolde ouirgoo
þerin solde he noþir leue onelyffe
beste ne man childe ne wyffe
that he ne sold þam bryne & sloo
than all þe folke of þat cete
rane þe geaunte for to see
at þe bretage þare he stode
bot als ferre als þay myghte hym se or ken
faste awaywarde gan þay ryn
for ferde þay were nere wode
there wente owte armede knyghtes fyve
& sayd þay wolde auenture þair lyfe
the geaunte thoghte it gode
full hastyly he hase þam slayne
skapede neuir one qwykke agayne
that owte vnto hym ȝode
when he had slayne the knyghtes fyve
agayne to þe walles gan he dryve
and ouir þe bretage gan lye
kynge dagaberde of fraunce he sayde
come thiselfe & fyghte a brayde
for thi curtasye
for j will with none oþir fyghte
thi heuede j hafe my leman highte
scho salle me kysse with thi
and if þou ne will noghte do so
alle this cete j will ouirgo
als dogges þan sall þay dy
grete dole it was þan for to see
the sorowe þat was in þat cete
bothe with olde and ȝonge
for þer was noþir kynge ne knyghte
þat with þat geaunt þan durste fyghte
he was so foulle a thynge
and ay jwhills arageous with his staffe
many a grete bofete he gaffe
and þe walles down gan he dynge
and þan gane alle þe pepille crye
vnto god & to mylde marye
with sorowe & grete wepynge
florent þan askede his fadir clement
whate alle þat ppetous noyes þan ment
and whedir þe folke so faste ren
clement saide my dere sone
a geaunte to þe walles es wone
hase slayne fyve of oure men
oure kynges hede hase he highte
the sowdan doghetir þat es so bryghte
for scho solde kysse hym then
there es no man dare with hym fyghte
forthi my dere sone hase he tyghte
this cete to breke and bryne
now fadir he sayde j hafe a stede
wanttes me no thynge bot wede
nowe helpes þat j were dyghte
a lorde why euir þus many men hym drede
me thynke j myghte do alle his nede
and j were armede ryghte
sayse clement & þou þerof speke
i trow j sall thyn hede breke
for had þou of hym a syghte
for all þis cete wolde þou habyde
bot faste awaywarde wold þou ryde
he es so fowle a wyghte
a fadir he said takes to none ille
for with þe geaunt fighte j wille
to luke if j dare byde
and bot j tittir armede be
i sall noghte lett so mote j the
that j ne salle to hym ryde
clement saide sen þou willt fare
i hafe armoures swylke als þay are
i sall þam lene þe this tyde
bot þis seuen ȝere sawe þay no sone
fadir he sayd alle es wonne
ne gyffe j noghte a chide
bot fadir he sayde j ȝow praye
that we ne make no more delaye
bot tyte þat j ware dyghte
for j wolde noghte for þis cete
that anoþir man before me
vndirtuke that fyghte
nay nay saise clement j vndirtake
þat þer will none swylke maystres make
noþir kynge ne knyghte
bot god sone sende þe grace wirchipe to wyn
and late me neuir hafe perelle þerin
to þe dede if þou be dyghte
for sorowe clement herte nere braste
when he one hym an actone caste
the childe was bolde and kene
ane hawberke abowne lete he falle
full ruysty weren þe mayles alle
and alle his atyre bydene
clement broghte forthe schelde & spere
that were vnsemly for to were
soyty and alle vnclene

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 801 through 900
DIV1.L: a swerd he broghte þe child byforne
þat seuen byfore had noghte bene borne
ne drawen & that was sene
clement drewe þe swerd bot owte it nolde
gladwyn his wyfe sold þe schawebereke holde
and bothe righte faste þay drewe
and when þe swerde owte glente
bothe vnto þe erthe þay went
than was þer gamen ynoghe
clement felle to þe bynke so faste
þat mouthe & nese al tobraste
and florente stode and loghe
grete gamen it es to telle
how þay bothe to þe erthe felle
and clement laye in swoghe
child florent in his vnfaire wede
whane he was armede on his stede
his swerde with hym he bere
his auentayle & his bacenete
his helme appon his heued was sett
and bothe full soyty were
bothe two clement & his wyfe
luffede þe child als þaire lyfe
for hym þay wepede sore
to jhesu criste full faste þay bede
lene hym grace wele for to spede
thay myghte do hym no more
for his atyre þat was vnbryghte
hym byhelde bothe kyng & knyghte
and mekill wondir þam thoghte
many a skornefull worde he hent
als he thurghe þe cete went
bot þerof gafe he noghte
than gane þe folke to þe walles goo
to see þe batelle bytwyx þam two
when þay were samen broghte
his fadir clement full sory was he
to þat he wyste wheþir maystir solde be
and glade ne was he noghte
florent come to þe ȝates full sone
and bade þe portere swythe vndone
and open þe ȝates wyde
all þat abowte þe ȝates stode
loughe so faste þay were nere wode
and skornede hym that tyde
ilk a man sayde to his fere
here comes a doghety bachelere
hym semes full wele to ryde
men may see by hys brene bryghte
that he es a nobylle knyghte
the geaunt for to habyde
bot þan þe geaunt vpryghte gan stande
and tuke his burdone in his hande
that was of stele vnryde
and to þe childe he smote so
that his schelde brake in two
and felle one aythire syde
than was þe childe neuir so wo
als when his schelde was in two
bot more he thoghte to byde
and to þe geaunt he smote so sore
that his righte arme flowe of þore
the blode stremyde þan full wyde
than clement appon þe walles stode
and full blythe he wex þan in his mode
and gan amende his chere
and said son j hafe herde j wene
the nobill dynt þat es so kene
with me þou arte full dere
now thynke me righte in my mode
that þou hase wele bysett oure gude
swylke lawes for to lere
childe florent in his vnfaire wede
spronge als sparke dose of glede
the sothe j will ȝow saye
and rode hym forthe with egre mode
to þe geaunt righte þer he stode
was þore no childes playe
the geaunt smote to þe childe so
þat childe & horse to þe grownde gan go
the stede one knes laye
than cryede clement with sory mode
and said sone be of comforthe gude
and venge the if þou maye
and als ill als the childe ferde
when he þe speche of clement herde
his herte bygan to bolde
boldly his swerde vp he laghte
and to þe geaunt a stroke he raughte
þat all his blode gan colde
the childe hym hitt one þe schuldir bone
that to þe pappe þe swerde gan gone
and þe geaunt to þe grounde gan folde
and thus it felle thorow goddes grace
he slewe þe geaunt in that place
in bukes als it es tolde
the kynges appon þe walles stode
when þe geaunt to þe grounde ȝode
the folke full blythe þay were
alle þe folke at the childe loughe

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 901 through 1000
DIV1.L: how he the geaunt hede of droghe
when he hade smetyn hym thore
the childe leppe vp appon his stede
and rode awaye wele gude spede
with þam spekes he no more
the childe toke þe ryghte waye
to þe castelle þer þe mayden laye
and the hede with hym he bare
when he come to þe mayden haulle
he founde the burdes couerde alle
and þam bowne to the mete
the mayden þat was mylde of mode
in a surkott in hyr haulle scho stode
and redy was to hir sette
damesele said florent faire & free
wele now gretis thi leman the
of þat he the byhete
lo here an heuede j hafe þe broghte
the kynges of france ne es it noghte
for it were full euylle to gete
that mayden brighte als golden bey
when scho þe geaunt heued sey
full wele scho it kende
and sayde he was ay trewe of his hete
when he þe kynges heuede myght not gete
his owen he hase me sende
damesele he sayde faire & bryghte
now wolde j hafe þat þat ȝe hym highte
and ouir his sadylle he lende
full ofte sythes he kyssede þat maye
and hent hir vpe & wolde awaye
bot þay alle þe brigge did fende
crye & noyse rose in thate towne
and sone þay ware to þe batelle bowne
full many an hardy knyghte
with speres longe and swerdes broune
and florent lete þe mayden downe
and made hym bowne to fyghte
hyre surkotte sleue he rofe of þen
and sayde by this ȝe sall me kene
when ȝe se me by syghte
swylke lufe wexe bytwix þam two
that lady grett so was hir wo
that he ne wyn hir myghte
childe florent in his vnfaire wede
full many a sarezene made he to blede
the sothe j will ȝow saye
many a hethyn man in a stownde
he made to lygge appon the grownde
was þer no childes playe
when florent thoghte þat he wold founde
withowtten oþir weme or wounde
to paresche he tuke the waye
the hethyn men were so adrede
to cleremont with the may þay flede
there þe sowdane laye
and jn hir fadir paveleone
thore lyghttede þe mayden down
and knelede appon hir knee
than was þe sowdane wondir blythe
and to his doghetir went he swythe
and kyssed hir sythes thre
he sett hir downe appon þe dese
that full riche was withowttyn lese
with grete solempnyte
scho tolde hir fadir & wilde nott layne
how arageous þe geaunt was slayne
a full sorye man was he
scho saide leue fadir thyn ore
at þe mont martyn late me lye no more
so nere crysten men to bene
in swylke ane auenture j was þis daye
a rebawde me hade nere borne awaye
fro alle myn knyghttes kene
thore was no man of hethen londe
that myghte a dynt stonde of his honde
þat he ne fellede þam bydene
als ofte als j appon hym thynke
i may noþir ete nor drynke
so full j ame of tene
bot when þe sowdane þis tythande herde
he his lippes & schoke his berde
that grymly was to see
and swore with hedouse contenance
that he sulde hange þe kynge of frauncce
and bryne alle cristyante
and þat he sulde noþir leue onelyue
man beste childe no wyfe
with eghene þat he myghte see
doughetir he said go to þi chambir
and luke þou make full glade chere
thow salle wele vengede be
full richely was hir chambir sprede
and thedir jn was þat lady lede
with birdis þat scho broghte
one softe seges was hir sete
bot myghte scho noþir drynke ne ete
so mekill scho was in thoghte
sumtyme one his faire chere
and one his coloure & one his lyre

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1001 through 1100
DIV1.L: scho myghte forgete hym noghte
full stylle scho saide with hert sore
allas þat j ne with my lemane wore
whedir he wolde me hafe broghte
one hir bede righte als scho laye
scho callede vnto hir a maye
full preualy and stylle
that mayden highte olyuayne
þat was full faire of blode & bane
and moste wiste of hir wille
scho saide olyue in preuate
my concelle j will schewe to the
that greues me full ille
for one a childe es alle my thoghte
that me to paresche wolde hafe broghte
and j ne maye come hym tylle
olyue hir answers tho
and sais lady sen ȝe will so
ne drede ȝow for no wyghte
for j sall helpe ȝow þat j may
bothe by nyghte and by day
that he wynn ȝow myghte
ȝitt may swylke auenture be
at ȝoure will ȝe may hym see
or this daye fowrtene nyghte
at þe monte martyne j wolde ȝe were
there salle ȝe somewhate of hym here
wheþir he be sqwyere or knyghte
the cristyn men þan were full blythe
when þay sawe florent onlyfe
þay wende he hade bene lorne
and when he come nere the cete
agayne hym wente kynges thre
and þe emperoure rode byforne
and to þe palayse þe childe was broghte
full riche atyre þay for hym soghte
of golde and syluir schene
men callede hym florent of paresche
for thus in romance tolde it es
þoghe he þer were noghte borne
and clement for þe childes sake
full faire to courte þay gan take
and gaffe hym full riche wede
one softe seges was he sett
amonge grete lordes at þe mete
and seruede of many riche brede
the childe was sett with grete honowre
bytwixe þe kynge & þe emperoure
his mete þay gan hym schrede
he was so curtayse & so bolde
þat alle hym louede ȝonge & olde
for his doghety dede
noghte longe aftir als j ȝow saye
the childe solde be knyghte þat oþir daye
no lengir wolde þay habyde
his atyre of golde was wroghte
byfore þe emperoure þe childe was broghte
a kyng one aythir syde
the kyng of fraunce byfore hym ȝode
with mynstralles full many and gode
and lede hym vp with pryde
clement to þe mynstralles gan go
and gafe some a stroke & some two
there durste noghte one habyde
clement so sorye was þat daye
for alle þaire costes þat he solde paye
that he gane wepe wele sore
and whills þe kynges dauwnsede in þe halle
clement tuke þaire mantills alle
and to his howse þam bare
than the kynges gan þaire mantills myse
and jlke man askede aftir his
where þay bycomen were
than swore clement by goddes daye
for ȝoure mete moste ȝe paye
or ȝe gete þam no more
thereatt all þe kynges loghe
there was joye & gamen ynoghe
amonges þam in the haulle
the kynge of fraunce with hert ful fayne
said clement brynge þe mantils agayne
for j sall paye for alle
clement þoreof was full blythe
and home he rane alsso swythe
to his owen haulle
and to þe palays he mantils bare
and bade þam take þam alle þare
and downe he lette þam falle
the burdes were sett & couerd alle
childe florent was broghte into þe haulle
with full mekill presse
the childe was sett with gret honowre
bytwyxe þe kyng & þe emperoure
sothe withowtten lese
the emperoure gan þe childe byholde
he was so curtayse & so bolde
bot he ne wiste what he was
and euir he thoghte in his mode
the childe was comen of gentill blode
hym thoghte righte als it was

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1101 through 1200
DIV1.L: when þe folke all had eten
clement hade noghte forgetyn
his purse he openede thore
thritty florence forthe keste he
and said hafe here for my son & me
i may paye for no more
clement was curtaise & wyse
he wend alle had bene marchandyse
the pryde that he sawe thore
at clement loghe the knyghtes alle
so did þe kynges in þe haulle
childe florent schamede full sore
than spekes þe emperoure anone ryghte
to florent þat was faire and bryghte
wordis full wondir stille
and said ȝonge knyghte telle þou me
if ȝone man thyn owen fadir be
the childe answerde hym till
sir lufe hade j neuir hym too
als j solde to my fadir doo
neuir in herte ne wille
bot of alle the men þat euir sawe j
moste lufes myn herte ȝowe sekirly
syr takes it to none ille
the emperoure did calle clement þere
and made hym come and sytt hym nere
oppon the heghe dese
he bade hym telle þe righte dome
how he to þe childe come
sothe withowtten lese
sir he said þis childe was taken in a foreste
fro a lady with a wylde beste
in ane grete wildirnes
and j hym boghte for thritty pownde
euirylke peny bothe hole and rownde
and sayde myn owen he was
than was þe emperoure joyefull & blythe
of his tales for to lythe
and thanked god almyghte
the emperoure felle one knes als swythe
and kyssede þe childe full fele sythe
thoghe he ne wiste whate he highte
for full wele he trowede withowtten lese
his owen sone that he was
alle gamnes bothe kyng & knyghte
the childes name was chaungede with dome
thay callede hym þan florent of rome
als it was full gude ryghte
the emperoure was so blythe of chere
that the teris trekelide one his lyre
he made þan full grete care
and said allas my faire wyfe
the beste lady þat was onelyfe
salle j hir see no mare
me ware leuir þan alle þe golde
þat euir was appon cristyn molde
wyste j onelyue scho ware
the emperoure gafe clement welthis fele
to lyfe in reches and in wele
aye nowe for euirmore
als florent one an nyghte in bede laye
he thoghte one marsabele þat faire maye
and full mekill he was in kare
the childe had noþir riste ne ro
for thoghte how he myghte com hir to
and whate þat hym beste ware
the childe thoghte for þe mayden sake
a message þat he wolde make
and to þe sowdane fare
and sone þe childe did sadill his stede
and armede hym in full riche wede
a braunche of olyue he bare
for þat was þat tym messangere lawe
a brawnche of olyue for to schewe
and it in hand to bere
for þe ordynance þan was so
messangers solde sauely come & go
and no man solde þam dere
the childe takes þe heghe waye
to cleremont þare þe sowdan laye
with alle his grete here
and at þe haulle dore he reyngened his stede
and one fote in he ȝede
messangere als he were
than spekes þe childe with hardy mode
byfore þe sowdane þere he stode
als man of mekill myghte
the kynge of fraunce me hedir sende
and byddis the owte of his lande wende
for þou werreys agayne þe righte
or he wille brynge agayne the
twentty thowsande tolde by thre
with helmes and hawberkes bryghte
and ilke a knyghte sall thritty sqwyers hafe
and ilke a sqwyere a fote knaue
worthe an heythen knyghte
than the sowdane bygane to speke
als he satt at his riche mete
amonge his knyghttes kene
the kynge of fraunce welecome sall be

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1201 through 1300
DIV1.L: euir agayne on j sall brynge thre
weite he withowtten wene
that als fayne bene for to fyghte
als fowle es of dayes lyghte
to schewe þaire scheldes schene
to prove tomorowe by my laye
i kepe to take no langere daye
than salle þe sothe be sene
than spekes þat may with mylde mode
to faire florent þare he stode
that was so swete a wyghte
messengir j wolde the frayne
wheþir he es knyghte or swayne
that es so mekill of myghte
that hase my fadir geaunt slayne
and wolde hafe rauesched me fra borow lerayne
and slewe þer many a knyghte
alle þoghe scho neuenede hym with ille
full mekill was it þan hir wille
of hym to hafe a syghte
lady he sayse he es noþir lesse ne moree
than it j myselfe wore
sythe ȝe will of hym frayne
ȝe sall hym knawe thurgh alle þe here
ȝoure sleue he wille hafe on his spere
in þe batelle al playne
withowtten any more worde
ilke man stirte vpe fro þe borde
with swerdes and knyues drawen
for alle þay wiste wele by þan
þat he it was þat ilke man
þat hade þe geaunt slayne
than florent sawe no bettir bote
bot nedely hym tydes to fighte one fote
agayne þe sarazenes alle
and euir he hitt þam amange
where he sawe þe gretteste thrange
full many he did to falle
sum by þe armes he nome
that the schuldir with hym come
the prowdeste in the haulle
and some he swilke a boxe lent
þat þe heued fro þe body went
als it were a foteballe
and when his swerde broken was
a mete forme he gatt par cas
and þerewith he gan hym were
and to þe grounde sone garte he go
ten score & somdele mo
that heythen knyghtes were
florent made a waye ful gode
to his stede righte þer he stode
there myghte no man hym dere
and home he takes þe righte waye
vnto parische als it laye
thurgheowte þe heythen here
than were þe crysten folke full blythe
when þay sawe florent onelyue
thay wende he lorne hade bene
and whene he come nere the cete
agayne hym went kynges thre
the emperoure rode bytwene
alle þe folke pressede hym to se
ilke a man fraynede whilke es he
als þay hym neuir hade sene
vnto þe palese he was ledde
he tolde þam alle how he had spede
amonge þe sarazens kene
lordynges he saide lukes ȝe be ȝare
vnto þe batelle for to fare
and redy for to ryde
tomorowe moste it nede be sene
who es hardy man and kene
no lengere ne may we byde
the folke sayde þat þay were blythe
to wende to þat batelle swythe
in herde es noghte to hide
a riche clothe one þe borde was sprede
to make þe childe bothe blythe & glade
a kyng one aythir syde
one þe morowe when þe daye was lyghte
the folke þam to þe batelle dyghte
alle þat wapen moghte welde
there men myghte se many a wyghte
with helmes schene & hawberke bryghte
with spere and als with schelde
with trompes & with mekill pryde
full boldly owt of borowe þay ryde
vnto a full brode felde
the felde was bothe longe & brode
þore bothe þe partyes one habode
and aythere oþir byhelde
marsabele þat mayden fre
was broghte þat batelle for to see
to þe mont martyne appon seyne
florent hir sleue did on his spere
for in þe batelle he wolde it bere
and forthe he rode in þe playne
for þat men solde wele se þan
that he it was þat ilke man

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1301 through 1400
DIV1.L: that haued þe geaunt slayne
and also for þat mayden free
was broghte þat batelle for to see
þereof scho was full fayne
than was þere mekill sorow in syte
when þe batelle bygan to smytte
with many a grymly wonde
fro morow þat þe daye was lyghte
to it was euen & dirke nyghte
or owthir partye wolde fownde
florent gan euir amonges ryde
and made þore many a sory syde
þat ore was hale & sownde
so many folke þore to þe dede ȝode
that stedis wode in the blode
that stremyd one the grounde
thore men myghte see helmes bare
and heuedis þat full faire waree
full lawe to þe grownde þan lyghte
the cristen men bycome so thyn
that the felde myghte þay noghte wyn
alle cryede bothe kyng and knyghte
than florent smote with herte so gude
his swerde thurghe þaire helmes wode
so mekyll he was of myghte
thurghe goddes grace & florent thore
the cristen men þe bettir wore
that ilke daye in þe fyghte
the parties ere withdrawen awaye
and taken there es anoþir daye
that the batelle sulde be
florent rode to borow lerayne
besyde þe watir banke of sayne
for auenturs wolde he see
the mayden whitt als lely floure
laye in a kirnelle of a towre
was ferly faire and fre
florent scho sawe on þe felde fare
by hir sleue þat he bare
scho knewe wele þat it was he
than spekes þat may with milde mode
to olyue þat byfore hir stode
þat wyste hir preuate
and saide howe were it beste to do
a worde þat j myghte speke hym to
i wysse than wele were me
scho saide lady we one two
by þe reuir banke sall go
that he may vs see
if he ȝow lufe with hert gude
he lettes nothyng for þe flode
a full gude horse haues he
forthe þan went theis maydenes two
owte of the castelle gan þay goo
by the reuere syde
when florent sawe þat swete wyghte
he sprent als any fowle of flyghte
no lengir þen wolde he byde
his horse he was full wondir gude
and bare hym smertly ouir þe flode
hymselffe couthe full wele ryde
it was grete joye to se þam mete
with haulsynge & with kyssynge swete
in herte es noghte to hyde
lady he sayde full wele es mee
a worde þat j may speke with the
so bryghte ert þou of hewe
in alle this werlde es non so free
for whi þat þow wolde cristenede be
and sythen of herte be trewe
sir if þat þou myghte me wyn
i wolde forsake all my kyn
als j þam neuir knewe
sythen þou wolde wedde me to wyfe
i wolde lyue in cristen lyfe
my joye solde euer be newe
lady he sayde withowtten fayle
howe were þan thi beste consaile
that j the wynn myghte
sertes ȝe me neuer wyn ne maye
bot if it were þat ilke daye
that ȝe hafe tane to fyghte
that ȝe wolde send vp by þe flode
men þat bene styffe and gude
and a schippe þat wele were dyghte
and ywhills þe folke weren at þaire dede
that thay me myghte awaye lede
into ȝoure cete full ryghte
my fadir has a nobille stede
in þe werlde es none so gude at nede
in tornament no in fyghte
in his heuede he hase an horne
es schapen als an vnycorne
that selcouthe es of syghte
sir if þou myghte þat stede now wyn
there were no man in heythen kynn
agayne the that stande myghte
florent kyssede þat faire maye
and sayd lady hafe gud daye
and holde þat þou hafe highte

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1401 through 1500
DIV1.L: florent hase his stede nomen
and ouir þat watir es he comen
to paresche he tuke the waye
he wolde neythir stynte ne blyn
bot home to clement gan he wyn
his awntirs for to saye
and tolde hym of þat gude stede
that nobille was in ilke a nede
and of that faire maye
and he said sone be doghety man of dede
and certes þou sall hafe þat stede
tomorowe gyff þat j maye
one þe morne when þe day was lyghte
clement gan hymseluen dyghte
lyke an vnfrely fere
and went into þe heythen oste
thore þe presse was alþirmoste
a sarazene als he were
and to þe paveleone he gan wynn
there þe sowdan hymselfe was jn
full brymly he gan bere
and askede þam sum of þaire mete
full wele he couthe þaire speche speke
the sowdane hymselfe gan here
grete dole þe sowdane of hym thoghte
and sone he was byfore hym broghte
and with hym gan he speke
he saide he was a sarazene stronge
and jn his oste hade bene full longe
and hade grete fawte of mete
sir þere es no man in heythen thede
that bettir kane ryde & kepe a stede
or oþir horsses grete
the sowdane saide þat ilke tyde
if þat þou wele a stede kan ryde
with me þou sall be lette
thay horsede clement one a stede
he spronge als any sparke one glede
appone a full faire felde
alle þat stode on ilk a syde
hade joye to se clement ryde
byfore the sowdans telde
and when he hade reden courses thre
alle had joye þat hym gan see
the sowdan hym byhelde
clement lyghtede down full sone
and one a bettir horse was done
full faire he gan hym welde
grete joye þe sowdan of hym thoghte
and badde his owen stede solde be broghte
and clement one hym solde ryde
and when clement was on þat stede
he rode awaye wele gud spede
no lengare he wold habyde
and when he was redy for to fownde
farewele he said heythen honde
for þou hase loste thi pryde
clement tuke hym þe heghe waye
vnto paresche als it laye
full blythe he was þat tydee
florent he said whore art þou
that j þe highte j hafe here nowe
i hafe þe broghte þe stede
florent was full blythe þat daye
and saide fadir if þat j maye
i salle þe ȝelde thi mede
bot to þe emperoure of rome
the stede j wolde were present sone
to þe palesse ȝe hym lede
for euir me thynke in my mode
that j ame comen of his blode
so prodly if j moghte spede
than to þe palays þe stede was ledde
the knyghttes were þan alle full glade
one hym for to see
the emperour byfore þam stode
and resceyuede hym with mylde mode
so wondir faire was hee
florent spak with grete
to his lorde þe emperour
sir this stede gyffe j
alle þat euir abowte
sayde he was comen
it moghte neuir oþir
aftir this þe day
that þe batelle
agayne þe
with trompes & with
boldely owte of
als men of mekill
florent thoghte
to þe batelle
a schipe sone
fro mont
to paresche he
wist noþir kyng
that while
when þe
with many a
fro morowe

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1501 through 1600
DIV1.L: to it euen &
with wondes
and for þat
the heythen folke
the batelle þay
or florent was to
the emperoure & the kyng
& þe cristen kynges all þat
than florent smote with herte
and rode thurgh þam als he
of witt als he wolde wede
thore was no sarazene of myghte ne
þat myght with strenghe stande hym agayne
whills þat he hade his stede
than was of florent dole ynoghe
how þay his stede vndir hym sloghe
and he to þe gronde þan ȝode
sir florent was taken in þat fyghte
bothe þe emperoure kynge & knyghte
bownden þay gan thaym lede
the
at þay ware
lese
was
þore
& oþir mo
also
full sore
firste man
l]ousede þan
lese
broþir florence
of fraunce
hate he was
as to hym comen
nomen
in prese
þat nobill dede
to spede
besyde
ryde
swythe
þore dyghte
and knyghte
and blythe
with grete honoure
the emperoure
he kythe
þat he þore tolde
ȝong and olde
þay were to lythe
in this lande j hafe þe soghte
modir j hafe with me broghte
to make hir pese
the emperoure was neuir so blythe
als for to kysse þe childe full swythe
and for his sone hym chese
lorde for a lessynge þat was stronge
scho was flemede owt of londe
i proue þat it was lese
for joye þat he his wiefe gan se
seuen sythes swonede he
byfore the heghe dese
faire florent þan was full blythe
of þat tydandes for to lythe
his modir for to see
lorde scho said for alle þe noye þat me was wroghte
thyn on childe j hafe the broghte
and ȝemede hym euir with me
thyn oþir sone in a foreste
was taken with a wilde beste
he was bothe faire & fre
alle j wote es goddes grace
i knowe hym by his faire face
that ȝone ȝong knyghte es he
than was þore full mekill gamen
with halsynge & with kyssyngez samen
into þe chambir þay ȝode
and full grete joye þere was also
at þe metyng of þe brethir two
þat doghety weren of dede
a riche feste þe emperour mad thare
of lordes þat were ferre and nere
and of many a londes lede
this tale whoso telles ryghte
the feste lastede a fourtenyghte
in romance thus we rede
marsabele þat faire maye
was aftir sent þe sothe to saye
to paresche righte þore scho was
cristenede scho was on a sonondaye
with joye & gamen and mekill playe
florent to wyefe hir chese
swylke a brydale als was þore
in that cete was neuir ore

DIV1.HEAD: Lines 1601 through 1634
DIV1.L: ȝe wiete withowtten lese
child florent þore hir gan wedde
and into rome was scho ledde
with prynces prowde in prese
and þen byfelle appon a daye
the emperoure bygan for to saye
and tolde alle how it was
and alle þan gafe juggement
that his modir sulde be brynte
in a belle of brasse
als sone als scho þerof herde telle
in swonynge to þe gronde scho felle
hir hare of scho gan rase
for schame þat scho was proued false
in two scho cutte hir owen halse
with a longe anelase
and þerat alle þe kynges loghe
there was joye & gamen ynowghe
alle tuke þaire leue that tyde
with trowmpes & with lowde songe
ilke a man wente to his owun londe
with joye & mekill pryde
with gamen & joye & grete honoure
to rome þan wente þe emperoure
his lady by his syde
and his two sonnes also
and with þam many one mo
home þan gan thay ryde
and thus endis octouean
that in his tym was a doghety man
with þe grace of mary free
now jhesu lorde of heuen kynge
thou gyffe vs alle thi dere blyssynge
amen amen par charyte amen
